ul.li1: 1How I wish that you were my little brother,Literally “O that he would give you like a brother to me”The Hebrew construction (which is somewhat misleading if rendered in a woodenly literal sense) is an idiom expressing one’s fanciful wish
ul.li2: who nursed upon my mother’s breasts!Literally “at the breast of my mother”
ul.li1: If I met you outside,Literally “I will find you in the street” I would kiss you,
ul.li2: and no one would despise me!Literally “also they would not despise me”
ul.li1: 2I would surely bring youLiterally “I would lead you and I would bring you”The combination of the two verbs creates a hendiadys which may be rendered more cogently as “I would surely bring you …” to the house of my mother,
ul.li2: who would surely teach me;Literally “she will teach me”
ul.li1: I would give you spiced wine to drink,Literally “I would give you to drink from the wine of the spice”
ul.li2: the sweet wineOr “juice” of my pomegranates.The traditional Hebrew reads the singular “my pomegranate.” However, the plural reading “my pomegranates” is attested in numerous medieval Hebrew manuscripts and is reflected in the ancient versions (Greek Septuagint, Aramaic Targum, Syriac Peshitta). The latter makes the most sense in this context as a euphemistic description of the maiden’s delights

ul.li1: 3His left hand is under my head,
ul.li2: and his right hand embracesOr “embraced” me.
ul.li1: 4I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem,Literally “O daughters of Jerusalem”
ul.li2: do notOr “Why must you … before it pleases?” arouse or awaken love until it pleases!Or “Do not stir up or awaken the love until it is willing,” or “Do not disturb or interrupt our lovemaking until it is satisfied”
